The main points from the article are:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) reported that soybean prices have increased by 8% over the past month, now averaging $12.50 per bushel nationwide. This is attributed to lower than expected soybean yields in the Midwest due to drought conditions.

Corn prices have also risen by 5%, now averaging $4.75 per bushel, due to similar crop challenges in major corn-producing states.

The USDA forecasts an overall 4% decline in total crop production for 2026 compared to the previous year. This is expected to impact farm incomes, which are projected to drop by an average of 7% across the country.

The American Farm Bureau is urging Congress to expand crop insurance programs and disaster relief funding to help offset these losses for farmers. Spokesperson Mary Johnson emphasized the importance of supporting family farms during these challenging times.

Weather forecasts indicate the drought conditions may persist through the summer, raising concerns about the 2027 growing season as well. Farmers are advised to explore water conservation techniques and drought-resistant crop varieties.

The Agriculture Today podcast provides regular updates on these industry trends and issues impacting the agricultural community.

items.title: Cotton Wholesalers Protect Demand Across Diverse Retail Channels
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – Cotton wholesalers help preserve broad-based demand by serving retail channels that would [...]
items.summary:
Key points:

- Cotton wholesalers serve retail channels that would otherwise struggle to source product efficiently, such as independent stores, regional chains, uniform programs, and workwear accounts. These retailers often lack the scale or capital to buy directly from factories.

- Wholesalers break large production runs into smaller, manageable assortments and replenishment programs, keeping these outlets viable. They also democratize access to compliance, traceability, and quality standards.

- Without wholesalers, retail assortments would narrow, buying would become more conservative, and out-of-stocks would increase. This would reduce cotton's retail footprint and concentrate demand among fewer players, increasing vulnerability across the supply chain.

- The article cites expert Bob Antoshak, who states that this "long tail" of retail plays a meaningful role in sustaining cotton consumption.

- The key takeaway for farmers is that wholesale distribution helps sustain the diversity of cotton demand.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, 4-8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime lows regularly dipped below zero, reaching -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. Strong winds also contributed to wind chills as low as -20¬∞F on some days.

It has been a dry week across Illinois, with 7-day rainfall totals ranging from around 0.5 inches in northeast Illinois to virtually nothing in southwest Illinois. January has been very dry so far, with Carbondale experiencing its 4th driest start to the month on record and Charleston its 10th driest.

The cold weather is expected to persist for at least another week, with temperatures struggling to break out of the single digits through the weekend. However, a strong winter storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall to southern Illinois, with 8-12 inches expected south of Interstate 64, and isolated higher amounts.

The article also includes a summary of recent WILLAg.org radio programming, which featured market analysis from experts Chip Nellinger, Brian Stark, and Arlan Suderman.

Key Takeaways:

- The second week of January 2026 saw unusually warm weather, with temperatures 8-12 degrees above normal. Kaskaskia and Carbondale reached highs of 69¬∞F and 68¬∞F respectively.

- January so far has been a top 10 warmest first half on record in most parts of Illinois.

- Precipitation has been below normal, with 7-day totals ranging from 0.1 inches in southeast Illinois to 0.75 inches in central Illinois. January is around 0.5-1 inch drier than normal statewide, except for a narrow area around Peoria-Chicago.

- This winter season has been slightly wetter than normal in northeast Illinois, slightly drier than normal in central/western Illinois, and much drier than normal (top 5 driest on record) in southern Illinois.

- The warm, dry weather will give way to much colder temperatures this weekend, with highs struggling to reach 20¬∞F in northern Illinois and just above freezing in southern Illinois. Little precipitation is expected, mostly light snow.

- The colder weather is forecast to persist through the first week of February, but precipitation chances improve in the final week of January.

items.title: Double-crop Soybean Management Practices – Project Report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction There is a growing interest in wheat/soybean double-cropping systems in Illinois, extending into parts of central Illinois where wheat acreage has been limited in recent decades. USDA-NASS survey estimates that 60-80% of Illinois wheat acres are double-cropped with soybeans. Implementing this system in central and northern Illinois has been constrained primarily by low wheat acreage and by later wheat harvest, which often delay
items.summary:
Key results include:

- Double-crop soybean yields averaged 55.7 bu/acre in 2024 and 47.8 bu/acre in 2025.

- Full-season soybean varieties (MG 3.6-3.8) yielded about 4% (2.1 bu/acre) more than early-maturing varieties (MG 3.0-3.2), likely due to a longer reproductive period.

- Yield response to seeding rate differed by maturity group - early varieties yielded max at 252,000 seeds/acre, while full-season maxed at 207,000 seeds/acre.

- Starter fertilizer (26 lb N, 11 lb S) increased yields by 1.4 bu/acre (2.6%) in 2024 only, likely not cost-effective.

- This research was conducted by the University of Illinois Crop Sciences Dept, in collaboration with the Illinois Agricultural Experiment Station, Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, and a local producer.

- The researchers note these are preliminary findings, and similar trials across more years/locations are ongoing to strengthen regional recommendations for double-crop soybean management.
